THOMSON CONSTITUENCY
(Request for now community centre)


    1. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Prirne Minister whether he is aware that the two small and outdated rural type community centres in Thomson Constituency are no longer adequate for their new role and if he will consider constructing a new community centre for the people of Thomson Constituency.

     The Senior Minister of State for Foreign Affairs (Mr Lee Khoon Choy) (for the Prime Minister): Mr Speaker, Sir, the People's Association is aware that the two

Column: 130

rural type community centres in Thomson are inadequate to serve the people in the Constituency. The hon. Member for Thomson may be happy to learn that a new and better equipped community centre has been included in the 5-year Development Plan of the People's Association. The Planning Department, the Land Office and the Housing and Development Board have been requested to locate a suitable site for the proposed centre.

JALAN BUKIT MERAH
(Request for pedestrian overhead bridge)

DEMOLITION OF VACATED PREMISES
UNDER CLEARANCE SCHEMES


    6. Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether he will consider and state what steps will be taken to ensure that empty premises vacated by persons affected by development programmes will be demolished speedily.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, my Ministry's objective is to demolish vacated premises speedily; however, it is not always possible to achieve this. Occupants of affected premises usually do not all move out at the same time. Since piecemeal demolition is not practical and poses safety hazards to remaining occupants in a block of

Column: 133

partially vacated premises, it is often not possible to proceed with the immediate removal of these empty structures. Even after premises have been totally vacated, it is often necessary to await the disconnection of overhead cables for utilities before the structures could be demolished.

    To expedite clearance, demolition of simple timber structures is presently done by the PWD using departmental labour. Where specialist demolition contractors have to be employed to remove concrete structures, tenders are timed to proceed as soon as buildings are ready for demolition. Where vacated structures cannot be immediately demolished, the Police are requested to provide more frequent patrols.

ST. MICHAEL'S ESTATE
(Installation of lifts)


    7. Dr Augustine H.H. Tan asked the Minister for National Development and Communications if he will ascertain from the Housing and Development Board whether and when the Board will install lifts in Blocks 14, 15, 16 and 17 of St. Michael's Estate.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, these blocks of buildings in St. Michael's Estate are six storeys high and are made up of 1-room self-contained and 2-room flats which have been converted from Emergency 1-room flats. They have not been designed to provide lifts, and to do so now would present the architects and engineers with very complicated structural problems.

    The Housing and Development Board, however, will sympathetically consider the requests of families with old people who wish to transfer from the higher floors to the lower floors to eliminate the need for old people to climb stairs

HOUSING BOARD FLATS REGISTER
(Retention of priority after rejections)


    8. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether the Housing and

Column: 134

Development Board will allow applicants for rental or purchase of HDB flats to remain on the register and still retain their priority after they have thrice rejected flats offered to them, on payment of a service charge for subsequent offers and rejections.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the ruling on balloting of new Home Ownership flats requires applicants who have rejected three offers to re-register if they still wish to purchase HDB flats. The ruling was introduced recently to check the frequent light-hearted rejections of completed flats in the new estates by applicants on the waiting list. The proposed payment of a service charge to retain their priorities would not help in achieving these objectives.

    The new ruling does not apply to rental applicants because most of them are in the lower income group and the percentage of rejections for rental flats is very low.

TOA PAYOH ESTATE
(Pricing of land for religious institutions)


    9. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) what are the criteria for the pricing of land offered to the various religious communities in Toa Payoh Estate; and (b) whether there is any uniform rate for all the religious communities, and, if not, what are the rates that have been fixed and offered to them.

     Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the pricing of religious sites in Toa Payoh and other estates is based on public tender. There is no uniform rate for all the religious communities as under the tender system the sites are usually allocated to the highest tenderers.

    In cases where religious buildings are required to be cleared for development purpose, a single site is made available to accommodate several resettlement cases combined together, for example, temples or

Column: 135

mosques. Under exceptional circumstances, a vacant site is offered to a religious institution to build. In these special cases, prices of land will be determined by the land valuer, in accordance with the prevailing market values at the time of offer and the locality of the site.

SBS BUS ACCIDENTS
(Particulars)


    10. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development and Communications, since 1st January, 1977, (a) how many Singapore Bus Service buses were involved in accidents; (b) what steps are being considered to improve the performance of SBS bus drivers for the better safety of other road users and bus passengers; and (c) how many SBS drivers have been reprimanded or dismissed for careless driving.

     The Minister for Culture and Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, from January to September this year, SBS was involved in a total of 3,648 accidents. These accidents included minor accidents such as falls or injuries sustained by commuters while boarding or alighting buses. This worked out to an average of 412 accidents per month.

    An analysis of available detailed statistics for the months of June to August this year showed that 78% of the accidents were minor, 22% were major and 0.4% were fatal. 56% of the accidents were due to the fault of SBS drivers.

    Steps have been taken to cut down the accident rate. A Training Department was set up in SBS in 1976 to improve the driving standards of bus drivers. Newly recruited drivers must undergo a minimum two-week practical-cum-theoretical familiarisation course which offers instruction in accident prevention, defensive driving and good driving habits. Intensive refresher courses are

Column: 136

also conducted for drivers with poor driving records. To-date, 334 drivers have attended these courses.

    An Accident Investigation Unit was also set up in SBS in April this year to investigate the causes of accidents involving SBS buses. The Unit co-ordinates with the Training Department in identifying the training requirements of drivers. The performances of bus crews are constantly being checked by field supervisors, ticket inspectors and timekeepers.

    Disciplinary measures are taken against erring drivers. These measures could be in the form of warnings, suspension from duties or dismissals, depending on the gravity of the accidents involved. On the more constructive side, SBS implements a productivity incentive scheme whereby good drivers are rewarded $1.50 per day whilst bad drivers are singled out for re-training with loss of incentive allowance.

    To emphasize the need for safety consciousness, safety driving seminars are occasionally c0nducted in conjunction with SILO.

    SBS is also imposing stricter standards of repair and preventive maintenance to ensure that accidents caused by mechanical faults are prevented.

    SBS has plans to extend its present two-week familiarisation course to provide a further week of on-the-job training under the close supervision of good and experienced drivers. A special campaign to apprehend speeding drivers is also being planned. The Vehicle Inspection Unit will be further strengthened to ensure that minimum safety standards are complied with.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, disciplinary action has been taken against 698 drivers for careless driving, from January to September this year. Of these, 592 were reprimanded, 102 suspended and four dismissed. In general, first offenders, in cases involving minor accidents, are given written warnings. Stiffer penalties are imposed for repeated offences. followed by dismissals.

TAXI DRIVERS AT SINGAPORE AIRPORT
(Work-stoppage incident)


    11. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) if he will throw some light on the recently reported incident of certain, taxi drivers refusing to pick up passengers and of stopping other taxi drivers from picking up passengers at the Singapore Airport; and (b) what steps his Ministry will take to ensure that passengers at the Airport will not encounter any transportation problems resulting from similar incidents in the future.

     Mr Ong Teng Cheong (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the incident mentioned by the hon. Member for Delta happened at about 11.45 p.m. on Monday, 24th October this year when some taxi drivers at the Airport ceased plying for hire and persuaded their colleagues not to go into the Airport. This incident arose when a team of detectives from Joo Chiat Police Station picked up seven drivers of Datsun taxis at Paya Lebar Airport. These drivers were taken to Joo Chiat Police Station for questioning regarding an incident involving a taxi driver who was alleged to have driven off his taxi with baggage belonging to a passenger. Unfortunately, the other taxi drivers at the Airport that night were not informed of the reason for picking up the seven taxi drivers in question. Due to the confusion and uncertainty created, some of the taxi drivers decided to stop work. Other taxis, particularly radio taxis, continued to pick up passengers. The number of passengers affected was small, numbering less than 40. All the taxi drivers resumed normal operations at about 1.30 a.m. on Tuesday morning when the seven drivers returned to the Airport. By then, nearly all the passengers had left the Airport.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the Registrar of Vehicles takes a very serious view of taxi drivers who refuse to ply for hire during their working hours. Taxi drivers involved in unlawful work-stoppages will be dealt with by the Registrar

Column: 138

of Vehicles. The Police have been requested to explain the reasons to taxi drivers at the Airport, should they wish to call up taxi drivers for questioning in the future. It is hoped that similar incidents will not occur again.

    However, it should be noted that alternative transportation at the Airport is also available in the form of shuttle bus and coach services. It is anticipated that the airport bus service will be improved next year, when an additional bus company starts operation.

SUNGEI WHAMPOA
(Cleaning up)


    12. Dr Augustine H.H. Tan asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology when steps will be taken to clean up the heavily-polluted Sungei Whampoa.

     The Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (Mr E.W. Barker): Mr Speaker, Sir, pollution in Sungei Whampoa comes from its catchment and mainly from indiscriminate dumping of refuse and discharge of sullage water into the drains from premises, in particular from squatter colonies. The present efforts to keep the river clean by desilting and removal of the refuse are only palliative measures. Until the sources of pollution on land have been eliminated, Sungei Whampoa will continue to be polluted.

    Sungei Whampoa is one of the five rivers or canals which flow into Kallang Basin. The other four water courses are Rochore Canal, Kallang River, Pelton Canal and Geylang River. The catchment itself covers seven constituencies, namely, Kolam Ayer, Kallang, Tanglin, Whampoa, Moulmein, Toa Payoh and Kuo Chuan. The catchment is less polluted than the other four catchments of the rivers which drain into Kallang Basin. However, during high tides, the polluted water from the Kallang Basin is carried into the upper reaches of the Whampoa River, thereby adding to the problems of pollution.

Column: 139



    The Ministry of the Environment is drawing up a programme to clean up the whole Kallang Basin. This will involve resettlement of squatters and the redevelopment of squatter areas and rundown parts of the city, the resiting of hawkers and farmers and the extension of sewerage facilities. This will take many years.

     Dr Augustine H.H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, first of all, how often is the silt and refuse removed from Sungei Whampoa, especially the stretch along Balestier Estate?

     Mr Barker: Sir, I would say as often as needed, depending on how dirty the canal is - usually about once a month.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, the Hon. Minister mentioned the number of squatters involved in the cleaning up process. I would like to know how many squatters will be affected in the cleaning up process?

     Mr Barker: Sir, I have details of these squatter premises. Going by constituencies, Kallang has 53 such premises. Whampoa has only eight. Toa Payoh has 63. Kuo Chuan has 35. Moulmein has 114. Tanglin has 274.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, the Hon. Minister said that it would take many years to do the cleaning up. May I know how many years will it be?

     Mr Barker: Sir, the Prime Minister has directed my Ministry to do this job within 10 years. But Members will realise that all these rivers have been polluted for more than 150 years. I would say that our target would be about the mid-1980s.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, may I request the Hon. Minister to clean up within 10 months?

     Mr Barker: We do take palliative measures. But 10 months would be impossible.

CANAL ALONG JALAN TOA PAYOH
(Cleaning up)


    13. Dr Augustine H.H. Tan asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and

Column: 140

Science and Technology whether and when steps will be taken to clean up the heavily-polluted and mosquito-infested canal along Jalan Toa Payoh, especially the stretch adjoining St. Michael's Estate.

     Mr Barker: Sir, this canal flows into Sungei Kallang. When the tide is rising, flotsam is carried into the canal from the polluted Sungei Kallang. The canal is polluted but, I understand, not mosquito-infested.

    My Ministry is drawing up a programme, as I have said, to clean up Kallang Basin involving the resettlement of squatter areas and rundown parts, resiting of hawkers and farmers and extension of sewerage facilities. All I can say to the Member is that the present efforts to keep the canal clean by desilting and removal of refuse, which as I have stated are palliative measures, will continue to be carried out until the whole Kallang Basin is cleaned up. In fact, my Ministry spends about $3,000 per month on the desilting of this canal.

     Dr Augustine Tan: Sir, is the Hon. Minister aware of the fact that the stretch of land alongside the canal is very uneven and that, in the event of rain, mosquitoes find a lot of breeding ground? Will the Minister therefore consider landscaping that piece of land?

     Mr Barker: Sir, I am not aware of the facts set out by the hon. Member. All I can assure him is that we will not only consider but we will landscape the sides of the canal to his delight.

LORONG BUANG KOK AND LORONG CHENG LIM
(Drainage system in farm areas)


    14. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology whether he is aware that the drainage system in the farm areas of Lorong Buang Kok and Lorong Cheng Lim is inadequate, and what plans the Ministry of the Environment has to improve the drainage system.

     Mr Barker: Sir, my Ministry is implementing a drainage improvement scheme in three phases in the Punggol/Serangoon area. The widening and deepening of Sungei Tongkang Pechah is in progress and will cost about $1.1 million. Tenders have been called for the widening, deepening and concrete lining of Sungei Tongkang along Lorong Buang Kok, near its junction with Yio Chu Kang Road.

HAWKERS
(Resiting of and licences for)


    15. Mr Teo Chong Tee asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology (a) how many more licensed street hawkers are presently awaiting to be resited in markets and hawker centres; (b) when the resiting exercise is expected to be completed; (c) whether the itinerant licensed hawkers will be given the opportunity, if they so request, to be settled in a permanent market or hawker centre; (d) whether the Minister will consider relaxing the rules governing the eligibility for issue of now hawker licences in the future: and (e) how many bona fide farmers affected by resettlement have been offered hawker licences to date.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology)( In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, there are 9,642 licensed street hawkers who need to be resited into markets and hawker centres.

    There are plans to resite 5,370 street hawkers into new markets and hawker centres by 1981. The street hawkers will have to take up stalls in markets/hawker centres which will be mostly built in new housing estates. The remaining street hawkers will be resited later depending on the availability of sites and funds.

Column: 142



    There are 528 licensed itinerant hawkers in Singapore comprising 400 ice-cream vendors, 106 bread hawkers and 23 pre-cooked food and sundry goods hawkers. It is already the policy of the Government to consider requests favourably from licensed itinerant hawkers for stalls in markets/hawker centres.

    Since 1976, out of 531 resettlement cases, 19 were bona fide farmers and were given stalls in markets/hawker centres.

    The existing hawker licensing policy has already been relaxed to issue licences to hardship cases. Since 1976, new hawker licences have been issued to 521 hardship cases. It will not be practical or advisable to liberalise the hawker licensing policy further until most of the 9,642 licensed street hawkers are resited into premises. Otherwise we will find it impossible to tackle the present hawker problem.

METRICATION
(Progress report)


    16. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Law, the Environment and Science and Technology whether any survey has been carried out by the Metrication Board to ascertain the percentage of the population conversant with the use of the metric system and whether there is the need to intensify efforts to familiarise the people with the use of the metric system.

     Mr Barker: Sir, a survey of housewives was carried out in October 1975 to determine their level of metric awareness. The survey showed that only about 50% of the housewives were familiar with the use of the system. The Metrication Board has since then embarked on an intensive campaign to educate the public by way of inter-school metric competitions, quizzes and even telemetric shows. Weekly "Metrication and You" exhibitions have so far been held in nine community centres and will be carried out finally in all constituencies. Members will perhaps agree with me that the conversion to the use of the metric system is a long-term process and must be implemented unhurriedly and in phases.

Column: 143



     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, as the results of the survey showed that only 50% of housewives were aware of metrication, will the Hon. Minister agree with me that the so-called exhibition at markets which provides the necessary information to housewives concerning metrication should be stepped up and that more personnel should be deployed to explain the conversion, so that more housewives will be conversant?

     Mr Barker: Sir, even some Members of Parliament have helped to explain. Perhaps when we reach Punggol, the Member will do his best to help. But it is a difficult process. Our people are more used to katis and tahils than to grams, litres, metres or centimetres. I am more used to feet and yards. I know what six feet is. But when someone says 1.8 metres, it does not strike a bell. The conversion must take time.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Sir, I would like to know whether the Minister will consider holding an exhibition in this Chamber for Members of Parliament to learn the conversion before they go out and teach the housewives?

     Mr Barker: With the permission of the Speaker, I would say yes.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, for the information of the Minister, I have taken part in such a campaign. As I have said, would he not step up the effort of the Metrication Board to encourage housewives to know more about metrication? I feel that the facilities accorded at such an exhibition stall at markets are grossly insufficient. I notice that the officials of the Metrication Board simply handed out pamphlets. If I can recall, with your permission -

     Mr Speaker: Mr Ng, the question you have put is not a supplementary question.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: In any case, Sir, will the Minister take note of my comments?

     Mr Barker: I certainly will, Sir.

    The present immigration law in Singapore had its origin in the Immigration Ordinance of 1952. The only major change during this period was the introduction of immigration control at the Causeway with effect from 1st July 1967.
